video.title: AWS Certified Developer - Associate 2020 (PASS THE EXAM!)
video.description:
The AWS Certified Developer - Associate examination is intended for individuals who perform a development role and have experience maintaining an AWS-based application. By the end of this full course taught by an expert trainer, you will be ready to take the AWS Certified Developer Associate exam - and pass!

🎥This course was too long to fit in a single video. Watch part two here (4 more hours): https://youtu.be/eCopK1RoyFM

✏️ Course developed by Andrew Brown of ExamPro. Check out the ExamPro YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2EsmbKnDNE7y1N3nZYCuGw
🔗 ExamPro AWS Obsessed Certification Training: https://www.exampro.co
🔗 LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/exam...
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/examproco
📷 Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/exampro.co/

⭐Course Contents⭐
Check the pinned comment for the course contents with time codes. This course is so massive the full contents won't fit in this description!

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Jared Branscum
topLevelComment.text: Hi, I'm not sure if you misspoke, but could you elaborate on how immutable deployments for EB is possible for single-instance web environments? The example you used refers to pointing the ELB to the new ASG, but single-instance web environments don't use load balancers. Can you please explain what you meant by this and how traffic gets routed to the new ASG? Thanks

replies.author: ATRAPS
replies.text: hi jared, I might be wrong but this is my thought process regarding your question. Single-instance web environment would consist of an EC2 instance with an Elastic IP attached. Although a single-instance environment does use the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling service, settings for the minimum number of instances, maximum number of instances, and desired capacity are all set to 1. Therefore, in an immutable deployment for single-instance web env, firstly a new ASG with min/max/desired=1 will be created. A new EC2 with the updates will be created. Once the new EC2 passes health checks, the traffic would be routed to the new ASG's EC2 which would have the original EC2's Elastic IP attached to it now. So there wont be a need for an ELB to point to the new ASG. From route53's perspective, it is still routing to the same Elastic IP address, it is probably just a matter of the Elastic IP switch from old EC2 to new EC2. This is just my two cents on this matter. I could be wrong.

replies.text: Depends on what you mean by that; practically every aws cert I'm aware of has an exam that is more memorization than anything. A peer who has no experience passed the Solutions Architect associate exam without much experience. Another who is a very poor developer managed to pass the Developer associate exam on his first try. If your company is paying for it go ahead and work on practice exams and aim to sit for a real exam in maybe 90 days. It's doable.

topLevelComment.author: Khiem Vo Duy
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed the exam on 24/04/2022. This training is good but it does not go into deep detail like CloudFormation syntax with hand-on, SAM, CI/CD. I also completed Udemy course from Stephane Maarek (highly recommended).
I took exam practice tests from Whizlaps and TutorialDojos and did twice for each test. First time I got 61%-65%, the second time I constantly got 76%-86%. I scored 800 in real exam, and you may get less than 5 questions which are similar to practice tests.
My advice is you need to seriously practice so you can remember all the syntax. My real exam focused on the majority of CloudFormation, SAM, CI/CD Code Deploy/Commit, and Encryption.

topLevelComment.author: HYZ
topLevelComment.text:
Some notes on the DynamoDB lesson ...

- DynamoDB scans are not less efficient because they "return everything", they're less efficient because they iterate all partitions. While queries fetch only from the partitions that are known to contain the data we're after.
- 5:26:59 - 20/4 equals 5. So 33 reads at 17gb per item would be 5 x 33 = 165 RCUs
- 5:28:22 - 24/4 equals 6. 14 reads at 24 KB = 42 RCU
- How does keeping the DynamoDB database smaller reduce cost? You don't pay per partition, you pay for RCU & WCU.
- Queries over GSI are not across the entire table, the query takes in a PK, so it's scoped to a partition.
- Queries on table do not require composite key, simple works too

topLevelComment.author: Baobab Koodaa
topLevelComment.text: 4:10:49 is pure nonsense (wrt asymmetric encryption): "From a security perspective, if you have to have two keys, one key matched to another, that is technically more secure, whereas if you have one key and that one key is lost then, you know, it's... it's less secure". We're talking about asymmetric encryption where you have a key pair of public and private key. I have no idea what Andrew even means when he ponders the possibility of "losing one key". Are you talking about "losing" the public key? That doesn't make sense. The key is public. Are you talking about accidentally erasing or leaking your private key? Neither of those options make sense either, in those cases the damage is compareable to accidentally erasing or leaking your (single) key in symmetric encryption.

topLevelComment.author: Minh-Phuc Le
topLevelComment.text: On Amazon Linux 2, using NodeCommand to run your application is now deprecated, you'll need to use Procfile instead. In fact you won't even need a Procfile if your command is just "npm start", it is used by default. NodeVersion is also deprecated on Amazon Linux 2, you can just ignore the 002_node_command.config file in this video entirely.

topLevelComment.author: jame089

If you're using amazon linux (amazon linux 1) as per the tutorial, you should be fine.
Just wanted to point that out.

topLevelComment.author: Abhim
topLevelComment.text:
I had given Cloud practitioner exam last month and had studied dedicatedly 5 hrs a day for a week then and passed that exam like a cake walk. I studied this video course for the developer exam and followed it throughout and completed the course in 2 weeks. Bought practice tests online and practiced them for a week, I did only 5 exams. Sturdiest about 5-6 hours a day. Final day of exam went through the cheat sheet links of this video course twice and then gave and passed my exam yesterday. I must say the Developer exam was super-duper tough. I had to think and rethink on the options I was to select. I lost a lot of time on some questions. I could not complete all questions and could answer 63 of the 65 questions in 130 mins. There was not a single direct question from the practice exams that I bought that appeared, but I think what would’ve helped me do correct selection of answers that led me to pass is : The knowledge and conceptual understanding that I had developed  when I sincerely completed the follow throughs of this video course and also the part I had studied for Practitioner exam that would’ve built my fundamentals and while going through the practice exams for this exam I went in detail about the explanation of the incorrect options as well alongwith the correct answer.

Thanks a lot to this course and freecodecamp for my journey in this certification, but anyone reading this I would like to tell the exam difficulty level I’ll say was very tough and to tell my background, I have 12 years exp in Software Dev, Design and Operations and good fundamental knowledge of Cloud computing but had no AWS knowledge prior to my AWS Practitioner. So all in all this exam is not a cake walk in anybody’s imagination.

replies.author: Antoine Masselot
replies.text:
I would recommend you go for the Solutions Architect Associate certification first, as this is an introduction to cloud (that goes quite far).
Developer associate does not focus on the basic building bricks you need to know to get started in the cloud for most of your use cases (storage, compute, network, databases, high availability, scalability, monitoring...). 
Developer associate focuses on how to deploy your applications to the cloud + use AWS Services to code your app (like Cognito, KMS etc...).
So: I'd recommend you start with Solutions Architect Associate first

Few items in the Elastic Beanstalk tutorial are outdated. 
1. In the process of Elastic Beanstalk env creation, users may face error for the Node JS version. Andrew used 10.18 version in the tutorial. Currently it is 10.22.0. Go for that.
2. 002_Node_Command_Config - adding start scripts through node command config is legacy. Instead, remove the file (using rm command). Navigate to application root directory. Create a file called ProcFile. add 'web: npm start' inside the file. Save & commit to Git. That helps to get over the Errors in Elastic Beanstalk environment creation step

topLevelComment.author: Sahil Shaikh
topLevelComment.text:
For all those who are wondering how to spin up the docker container in cloud9, here are the steps
1. Create two files in your project directory. 
         a) Dockerfile   b) .dockerignore
2. Copy and paste below cod in your Dockerfile
# we'll use 10 since its same as Amazon Linux 1 default node version
FROM node:10
# where our app will be located in the image
RUN mkdir /app
WORKDIR /app
# move all source code
COPY . .
RUN npm install
CMD [ "npm", "start" ]
EXPOSE 8080
2. Paste this into your .dockerignore file
node_modules
3. Execute below command to build your docker image (make sure you are in your project directory)
docker build --tag study-sync:1.0 .
4. Now run the docker container
docker run --publish 8080:8080 --name ss study-sync:1.0
Note: You can also build and run the docker container with one command.

topLevelComment.author: first name last name4
topLevelComment.text: 54:50 actually I am confused, even if the database is outside of the beanstalk environment, in-place deployment doesn't matter, right? The instance upgrade is happening inside in the environment, the database is still connectable, right?

replies.author: first name last name4
replies.text: @ExamPro ok , i get, for the case that the database is outside,  either in-place or bluegreen is fine.        Thanks so much for the free course. It is insane that the  youtube ads isn't even switched on.

replies.author: ExamPro
replies.text: With Blue/Green you are replacing the entire environment. So if your DB was created by EB its going to get destroyed. For In-Place with DB created by EB you're right it doesn't matter, but in practice, you should always use a DB outside your environment for production since one day a junior developer can decide to do a Blue/Green deployment without the realization its going to be a problem.
